body:
yes, especially problematic because some js and css are generated on the
fly, and they need session_start too. memcache does improve situation, but
its not perfect.

stephane



on tue, sep 10, 2013 at 5:19 pm, pellaeon lin <notifications@github.com>wrote:

> i've done some profiling with owncloud, below are the four requests fired
> while getting /index.php/apps/files
> [image: 1]<https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/916913/1105074/6dcc4588-1918-11e3-9943-7eba5b2942b9.png>
> [image: 2]<https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/916913/1105076/6dd3806e-1918-11e3-8bf3-8e74ed1b8987.png>
> [image: 3]<https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/916913/1105075/6dd86fc0-1918-11e3-8280-cd9989fd278b.png>
> [image: 4]<https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/916913/1105077/6dd3f0b2-1918-11e3-96fd-b280b02d85ba.png>
>
> for all 4 requests, session_start() takes up big portion of time.
> while not sure, i think the most likely cause is php's session blocking
> problem. http://www.php.net/manual/en/function.session-start.php#101452
>
> same problem was reported in #2372<https://github.com/owncloud/core/issues/2372>
> .
>
> if we optimize owncloud's session handling, we would probably reveive a
> huge performance gain.
>
> â€”
> reply to this email directly or view it on github<https://github.com/owncloud/core/issues/4794>
> .
>
owncloud already supports different sessionmanagement backends.
